title: Environmental Sustainability and Behavioral Science
abstract: To provide practitioners with useful information about how to promote proenvironmental behavior (PEB), a meta-analysis was performed on 87 published reports containing 253 experimental treatments that measured an observed, not self-reported, behavioral outcome. Most studies combined multiple treatments, and this confounding precluded definitive conclusions which individual are most effective. Treatments included cognitive dissonance, goal setting, social modeling, prompts provided the overall largest effect sizes (Hedge’s g > 0.60). Further analyses indicated different have been more effective for certain behaviors. Although average based small numbers of studies, combinations behaviors making it easy recycle, setting goals conserving gasoline, modeling home energy conservation. The results also reveal several gaps in literature should guide further research, including both PEB tested.

title: Employee Green Behavior as the Core of Environmentally Sustainable Organizations
abstract: Environmental sustainability has become an ethical and strategic imperative for organizations, more employees are interested, encouraged, or instructed to act in environmentally sustainable ways. Consequently, organizational scholars have increasingly studied individual-level antecedents of employee pro-environmental green behavior (EGB). We argue that, advance this literature inform effective interventions, research should investigate how EGB, as a compound performance domain, is associated with consequences at multiple levels (i.e., individual, team, work context, organization, society). Accordingly, we pursue three interrelated goals review. first present comprehensive review on including definitions, theoretical frameworks, methodological approaches, empirical findings. Second, develop integrative conceptual model EGB the core environmental sustainability. Third, conclude recommendations future theory development improvements, well practical implications employees, leaders, human resource management.

title: Assessing nutritional, health, and environmental sustainability dimensions of agri-food production
abstract: Agri-food production systems are major drivers of global sustainability challenges including climate change, freshwater scarcity, micronutrient deficiencies, and cardiovascular disease. There is an urgent need for more robust methods (e.g., life cycle assessment, system-based modelling) metrics Disability-Adjusted Life Years, nutrient diversity indicators) to quantitatively assess the these on a joint nutritional, health, environmental basis. Creating sustainable future will require actors co-develop co-implement interventions across groups; presently, however, fields misaligned. Current siloed, qualitative, calorie- or food- based, they should be developed in holistic, quantitative, nutritionally-focused manner. Developing data-driven interdisciplinary approaches can help alleviate food security challenges.

abstract: Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4), with facile synthesis, unique structure, high stability, and low cost, has been the hotspot in field of photocatalysis. However, photocatalytic performance g-C3N4 is still unsatisfactory due to insufficient capture visible light, surface area, poor electronic conductivity, fast recombination photogenerated electron-hole pairs. Thus, different modification strategies have developed improve its performance. In this review, properties preparation methods are systematically introduced, various approaches, including morphology control, elemental doping, heterojunction construction, nanomaterials, discussed. Moreover, applications energy environmental sustainability summarized, such as hydrogen generation, CO2 reduction, degradation contaminants recent years. Finally, concluding remarks perspectives on challenges, suggestions for exploiting g-C3N4-based photocatalysts presented. This review will deepen understanding state art g-C3N4, fabrication, modification, application sustainability.

title: Native Grasslands at the Core: A New Paradigm of Intensification for the Campos of Southern South America to Increase Economic and Environmental Sustainability
abstract: Extensive livestock production in southern South America occupies ~0.5 M km 2 central-eastern Argentina, Uruguay and Brazil. These systems have been sustained for more than 300 years by year-long grazing of the highly biodiverse native Campos ecosystems that provides many valuable additional ecosystem services. However, their low productivity (~70 kg liveweight/ha per year), at least relative to values recorded experiments best farmers, has driving continued land use conversion towards agriculture forestry. Therefore, there is a pressing need usable, cost effective technological options based on scientific knowledge increase profitability while supporting conservation grasslands. In early 2000s, existing was synthesized path six sequential steps increasing intensification. Even though higher underlined path, it recognized trade-offs would occur, with increases being concomitant reductions diversity, resilience droughts, exposure financial risks. Here, we put forward proposal shift current paradigm away from linear sequence toward flexible dashboard intensification be implemented defined modules within farm whose aims are (i) maintain grasslands as main feed source, (ii) ameliorate its two major productive drawbacks: marked seasonality relatively rapid loss nutritive value-hence title “native core.” At center, highlights key role optimal management maintaining system wide costs risk, but acknowledges achieving required spatio-temporal control intensity requires using (a portfolio of) complementary, synergistic options. We sum up experimental evidence case studies hypothesis integrating both environmental sustainability ecosystems.

title: Paleolimnology as a Tool to Achieve Environmental Sustainability in the Anthropocene: An Overview
abstract: Lacustrine sediment accumulation provides meaningful and diverse long-term records of environmental change. This overview highlights the usefulness paleolimnological approach in evaluating magnitude direction human-induced change lakes their catchments. title: Managing environmental sustainability in a healthcare setting
abstract: How does a hospital sustain its journey towards environmental sustainability? To date, most hospitals have embarked on some strategies for improving performance, whether it's reducing energy or landfill waste. Environmental sustainability strategies, however, can often lose momentum stagnate if not championed by someone whose full-time role is to assess, monitor, and bring new the table. In face of ongoing budget deficits, it increasingly difficult get adequate support buy-in this type unless leadership organization committed an program. This article will examine outcomes plan one from 2008 present, including best lessons learned, what lies ahead us in world capping greenhouse gas emissions.

title: Environmental sustainability and sport management education: bridging the gaps
abstract: Although sport management higher education has recognized the need to include environmental sustainability in curricula, little is known about scope and content of curricula. This study conducted an inventory courses offered programs. A questionnaire was distributed 553 faculty members from North American institutions. Additionally, a panel experts were interviewed benefits, drawbacks challenges including curriculum. Findings reveal that very few programs currently have stand-alone dedicated sport. There are significant barriers adopting as course module, which certainly makes developing coursework long-term process. However, these not stopped many incorporating topics into their other creative ways. The paper suggests ways overcome integrate education.

(1992) Ecological Footprint proposed Wackernagel Rees (1996). The environmental sustainability index (ESI) is a composite index, which was created World Economic Forum, Yale Columbia Universities, aggregating data at national level country's performance in sustaining healthy, livable environment. 142 countries measured with ESI 2002. However, it not yet documented if can be applied regional level. this study, we tried apply of Shandong China. 22 indicators 43 variables were chosen, results showed 49, suggesting that still far from position development.
